A large city is considering increasing the number of buses running on a certain route. To determine whether there is a need for more buses, a random sample of <math alttext="58" overflow="scroll"><mn>58</mn></math> people at bus stops along the route is selected. The amount of time a person waits until a bus arrives is recorded to the nearest tenth of a minute for each person. The histogram shows the distribution of wait time. The first bar includes values from <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="1.9" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.9</mn></math> minutes, the second bar includes values from <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> to <math alttext="3.9" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.9</mn></math> minutes, and so on. (a) Based on the distribution of wait time shown in the histogram, what would be a statistical advantage of using the sample median rather than the sample mean as the estimate of the typical wait time?

(c) Based on the histogram, the smallest possible interquartile range (<math alttext="I Q R" overflow="scroll"><mtext>IQR</mtext></math>) for the wait times is <math alttext="4.1" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.1</mn></math> minutes and the largest possible <math alttext="I Q R" overflow="scroll"><mtext>IQR</mtext></math> for the wait times is <math alttext="7.9" overflow="scroll"><mn>7.9</mn></math> minutes. Which of these two <math alttext="I Q R" overflow="scroll"><mtext>IQR</mtext></math> values would identify more wait times as potential outliers? Justify your response.
